(41) 104thConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.naval operations.Shipping Losses.MilitaryOperations.U.S.S.R.YugoslavRebellion.Home Theatre Enemy 17 destroyed.4 probable.7 damaged.Otir Own 13 Fighters.20 Bombers.3 Coastal Command Aircraft.Overseas Theatre Enemy 1 probable.1 damaged.Our Own 8 destroyed.7 damaged.In Home Waters one small vessel had been hit and twoprobably hit. In the Mediterranean two enemy merchant vessels had been set on fire and one schooner, carrying ammunition,destroyed. Two promising attacks had been made on submarineson the 21st and 22nd October. Naples had been attacked on the night of the 21st/22nd with satisfactory results.Of forty-nine enemy aircraft which had operated against thiscountry on the previous night (not all over land), three had certainlybeen destroyed and one probably.During the previous three days, excluding the U.S. ship Lehigh,4,000 tons of shipping had been sunk and 8,000 tons damaged.On the Northern fronts there had been no change. South ofLeningrad the Germans had crossed the River Volkhov at twoplaces, but their attacks had been held. There had been heavy fighting in the Kalinin sector.In the Central Sector a break-through near Mohaisk had beenheld. In the Kharkov area there had been no change, but thesituation was difficult in the Donetz Basin. The Germans hadwidened their front north of the Sea of Azov by the capture ofStalin, and their attack on the Crimea had been renewed.General Zhurkov was now in command of the Central sector and Marshal Timoshenko of the Southern Sector. MarshalsVoroshilov and Budenny were being employed in raising newformations.The Permanent Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairsenquired if we were in a position to inform Yugoslav authoritieswhether we could give any help available to those forces who had raised the standard of revolt in Yugoslavia.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that telegramshad been sent to the Commanders-in-Chief in the Middle Eastimpressing on them the importance of affording help.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.[23049] Air Raids. 2. Affairs said that the American Ambassador had approached theForeign Secretary in regard to the establishment of air bases in the pacific, for an air route from Honolulu to the Philippines. the ambassador had suggested that, if the matter could be settled inprinciple, arrangements could then be made for officials of the war department to make contact with local officials in the Pacificterritories concerned.After a short discussion, in the course of which the Secretaryof Sta,te for Dominion Affairs said that it would be necessary to approach the Dominion Governments in this matter The War Cabinet Invited the Foreign Secretary, in consultation with theMinisters concerned, to arrange for the issues involved tobe carefully examined and a considered recommendationsubmitted to them.France.Fulfilment of undertakings by great Britain.(previous reference:W.M. The War Cabinet had before them a Note by the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs (W.P. (G) (41) 114) explaining that afull record of the facts regarding our pre-war obligations to Franceand the steps taken to give effect to them had now been prepared,but that it was undesirable to publish any public statement on thesubject at the present time.The War Cabinet expressed agreement with this view.6. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum on thissubject by the Foreign Secretary (W.P. (41) 245).In this Memorandum the view was expressed that thearguments against declaring war on these three countries wereoutweighed by the importance of not rebuffing or discouraging ourRussian allies.The Home Secretary gave particulars of the number of aliensof the countries concerned in the "United Kingdom, which were asfollows : FinlandHungaryRoumania5003,7002,700 Plans had been agreed between Departments as to the steps tobe taken as regards Hungarians and Roumanians in this country if war was declared. As regards Finland, there were between 200and 300 Finns serving either in British ships or in Scandinavianships chartered to the British Government who were willing tocontinue in this service so long as there was no outbreak of war.If, however, war was declared, they could not continue to serve inthe British service. It did not, however, follow that they wouldhave to be interned.The general view of the War Cabinet was that the disadvan-tages of declaring war on these three countries were considerable.No action could, however, be taken, or any final decision reached,until we had consulted the United States of America and theDominions.The point for immediate decision, therefore, concerned theterms of the communications to be sent to the U.S.A. and theDominions. The general view of the War Cabinet favoured a balanced statement of the position, making an enquiry as to theviews of those Governments, but without expressing any decidedpreference for declaring war on Finland, Hungary and Roumania.The Foreign Secretary was invited to prepare draft telegrams to the United States and to the DominionGovernments (the latter in consultation with the dominions secretary) and to submit them to the Meeting of the WarCabinet to be held on Monday, the 27th October.Great George Street, S.W. 1,October 23, 1941.
